story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
"... That has always been the danger when it comes to how we discuss Africa. There has always been the assumption of a monolith: 
Africa as one country, not 54;
One culture, not an immeasurable number; 
One climate, hot! hot! hot! 
Africa as one intractable reality.

When you hear the name Africa spoken on television or radio or in an unfamiliar public space; When you read the name Africa in a newspaper or magazine, do you, for even the briefest of moments, wonder about the story that will follow? Which Africa will it show?"

-President JD Mahama in his address to open the Oxford Africa Conference 2015 at the University of Oxford. 

#ChangingLives  #TransformationAgenda

Read the full speech by clicking http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/953

Photos are also available at https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157652846109220

"Horrified @ murder of UE NPP Chair Adam Mahama. Nothing can justify such barbarism. Condolence to wife & family. There'll be justice.-- JM." 

My tweet moments ago.

President John Dramani Mahama has handed over the Chairmanship of the sub-regional body, ECOWAS to President Macky Sall of Senegal.

Handing over the gavel and ECOWAS flag to Mr. Sall at the end of the 47th Ordinary Session of the ECOWAS Authority of Heads of State and Government in Accra, President Mahama indicated his preparedness to assist and support the new Chair. 

President Mahama was originally scheduled to hand over in March, but a meeting of the Heads of State and Government in Abuja rescheduled the election of a new Chair to May.

Giant progress in the fight against Ebola. Congratulations Liberia, UNMEER & the 42 Ghanaian Health Volunteers.
---JM

Here's to all mothers of Ghana, most especially Abiba Nnaba, my mother, and her daughter-in-law, Lordina. 
---JM.

"Your re-election to a second term demonstrates the confidence that the British people have in your leadership. It is my hope that during your new term in office, we shall continue to work together towards the strengthening of the existing bonds of friendly relations between our two nations, while sustaining the mutually beneficial partnerships between our two countries and peoples.

"Please accept, Rt. Hon. Prime Minister, my very best wishes for the personal well-being, a successful tenure, peace and continued prosperity of the British people."
--- President JD Mahama in a congratulatory message to the re-elected Prime Minister of Britain.

Accra Sea Water Desalination Project- 
One of the many community improvement projects being implemented by the John Dramani Mahama administration across Ghana.

The #ChangingLives Documentaries lay bare how these projects are benefitting and impacting the lives of the people in the communities they are sited and beyond.
story: John Dramani Mahama at The Flagstaff House.

Message:
"There had been some concerns raised by our brothers, Togo and Benin, with respect to the management of the Accra Flight Information Region. An MOU had been signed earlier in 2008 that had not addressed those concerns or was not effectively implemented. 

"A notice was given to disaggregate the Benin and Togo flight information regions into ASECNA, to hand over management of them to ASECNA. I therefore called the meeting of my colleagues from Togo and Benin to discuss the issues of concern to both countries and also to demonstrate our commitment to maintain the Accra Flight Information Region as one single entity."

--- President JD Mahama speaking to journalists after a meeting at the Peduase Lodge in Aburi with the Presidents of Togo and Benin. 

#ChangingLives #TransformationAgenda

Visit our website for the story on the meeting- http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/922

Click below link for photos of the Peduase Meeting- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157652271299555/

"Our Agenda for Transformation as a country is kicking in, and I commit to the people of Ghana, that I will, as President, continue to focus on working to achieve that which we have set ourselves- that is transforming our economy to become a net exporter of goods rather than an importer. Today and here in Tema, we are inaugurating a new cocoa processing plant, which is a major contribution to our policy of processing at least 50% of our cocoa locally. Touton’s average annual trading in Ghanaian cocoa is about the value of US$350million. They will not only be spending $350 million annually on our cocoa but they have invested in a processing factory worth millions of dollars, and this comes with the associated benefits including employment of our hardworking youth and thereby improving the living conditions of our people. Again, the decision by Touton to choose Ghana out of the many countries in which it does business to build its first processing plant is another demonstration of the confidence that Touton has in the economy of Ghana."

--- President JD Mahama speaking at a ceremony to inaugurate a new cocoa processing factory in the Tema Free Zones area on April 24, 2015. 

#ChangingLives #TransformationAgenda 

Visit http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/920 for the President's full speech.

Photos of the inaugural ceremony are available at: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157651710032827/
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
"Our public service must be noted for nothing other than Quality, Effective and Efficient Service Delivery. That is what I desire and that is what the people of Ghana desire from you. Accountability to the people is absolutely, absolutely necessary. Members of the public are not irritants. They are the reason for our being. That is why we are called the Public Service and that is why those who work in the Public Service are called Public Servants. It means you are servants of the public. So when the public interface with you, they have not come to irritate you, they have come to demand what is rightfully theirs, service. And that is the service we must give them. The public is the reason for our being and we must provide efficient and friendly service to them. The desired leadership of some organisations is low and lacking and it is necessary to conduct an occasional review and realignment of personnel.
We do it routinely for the political class. That is when I reshuffle ministers and there is no reason why we should not extend it to public service institutions."

--- President JD Mahama opening the 8th Annual Conference of Chief Directors, CEOs and Chairmen of Governing Boards and Council at Koforidua on April 25, 2015. 

Read the President's full speech at http://presidency.gov.gh/node/918

View for more photos of the opening ceremony at https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649845109423/

"The desalination plant, which we are commissioning today, ends more than 25 years of water poverty that has bedevilled the people of Nungua and surrounding communities. With this project, we are producing and pumping to homes and businesses 13 million gallons of water every day to the catchment area around Teshie and Nungua."

President Mahama speaking at a ceremony to inaugurate the $115million Accra water desalination project on Friday April 17, 2015. 

#ChangingLives #TransformationAgenda

Click for more photos of the ceremony-- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649696223153/

Visit http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/910
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
The people of Zenu-Katamanso in the Greater Accra Region now have access to potable drinking water. The community, which is right behind Ashaiman, has never had pipe distribution lines. As part of the Kpong Water Supply Expansion Project, we have extended pipelines to the area and on Friday, I joined the chiefs and people to inaugurate the facility. 

#ChangingLives #TransformationAgenda 

Visit for more photos: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649696197413/
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

story: John Dramani Mahama shared a link.

Message:
I spent a greater part of Tuesday visiting and interacting with the management and staff of two aluminium companies, VALCO and ALUWORKS, which both require consistent power supply to operate at full capacity. VALCO is currently operating only one out of its 5 pots, which in turn affects the production capacity of ALUWORKS because it relies on VALCO for its raw materials. 

In addition to VALCO working to secure its own 450MW gas-fired plant, they have also prepared and are fully ready to operate a second pot once we are able to increase supply to them, when the current power supply challenge eases a little.  

The integrated aluminium industry holds great prospects for this country, and my discussions with VALCO outlined government's vision to roll out the integrated aluminium industry architecture. 

#ChangingLives #Transformation

For more photos, please visit, https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets
For videos, please visit, https://www.youtube.com/user/flagstaffhouse
For audio, please visit, https://soundcloud.com/flagstaffhouse

"Enclave Power is a private entity and has the concession to distribute power in the Free Zones enclave and they have been doing this since 2009.

Everywhere in the world, private sector participation in many areas hitherto monopolised by government is being encouraged. This is leading to increased investment from the financial sector and the capital market and it is introducing efficiency into the operations in those sectors.

Power can be no different. Therefore when people try to misinform the nation and the public by saying that our carrying out the reform in terms of allowing private sector participation in concessions and the distribution of power, by that we are privatising ECG, it is absolutely untrue."

--- President JD Mahama in a speech to officially inaugurate a $35m privately owned and constructed substation in the Tema free zones enclave.

story: John Dramani Mahama at Flagstaff House.

story: John Dramani Mahama with Joaquim Chissano at Flagstaff House.

Message:
"One of the issues we discussed with Chancellor Merkel was our agreement to send a letter to the UN Secretary General signed by Chancellor Merkel, the Norwegian Prime Minister and myself to suggest the setting up of an international panel of eminent persons to investigate the world’s international crisis response in terms of matters to do with health, like we had with the Ebola crisis. And the reason for that was to make it possible for the international community to respond much quicker and more efficiently than we did in the case of the recent Ebola outbreak. Just a few days ago I was very pleased to receive a response from the UN Secretary General accepting our proposal and indicating that the UN was going to work with us to set up such a panel and they hope that we would assist so that we can set up a better international crisis response system."

--- President JD Mahama, speaking during a courtesy call by Germany's Minister for Economic Cooperation Gerd Muller, and the Minister for Health Hermann Groehe. Thursday, April 09, 2015.

https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157651852623911/

Congratulations General Muhammadu Buhari, President-elect of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. Thanks for contributing towards the peaceful conduct of Nigeria's historic elections, which marks an important milestone, not only in the democratic development of Nigeria but also the continent as a whole.

I also extend my congratulations to all the political stakeholders, electoral officials and the people of Nigeria for their belief and commitment to the strengthening of democracy and good governance. 

To President Goodluck Ebele Jonathan, you have displayed great political maturity and statesmanship. 

Congratulations Nigeria.

I received the report of the Presidential Commission of Enquiry into our participation in the 2014 World Cup in Brazil. On behalf of all Ghanaians, I thank Justice Senyo Dzamefe and his colleague Commissioners, Moses Foh Amoaning and Kofi Anokye Darko for the hours and efforts that they put into the work. 
Government will speedily review the report and the recommendations and take the necessary actions in the Supreme interest of our dear nation. 

Click here for more photos of the presentation-  https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649332637063/

Ahead of Nigeria's elections on March 28, I spent today, Monday, in Abuja to confer and interact with the key stakeholders in the elections, and discuss issues arising out of the ECOWAS monitoring group's reports. It is clear that Nigeria is all ready, and will come out of the March 28 elections stronger and much more democratic. 

I was joined in my meetings with President Goodluck Jonathan, General Buharu, the INEC Chairman and Heads of the AU & Commonwealth Observer Missions by the President of the ECOWAS Commission. 

Click to read and follow my pre-election visit to Nigeria. http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/872
story: John Dramani Mahama added 3 new photos.

Message:
The former Secretary General of the United Nations, Mr. Kofi Annan, was my guest on Sunday for discussions on a wide range of issues. He was accompanied by a member of the Presidential Advisory Group on the Economy, Kwame Pianim.

Click here for more photographs--- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649171687514/

On Friday, I visited the Central Plant Pool of the Ministry of Local Government and Rural Development, and handed over a number of equipment for routine road maintenance in our rural communities. These included 5 dozers, 20 trucks, 60 graders, 10 excavators and 20 loader.  

Our MMDAs will have access to the equipment, which will be stationed in three zones, for the construction of feeder roads, grading, upgrading and also for spot improvements. This will help ensure that the feeder roads in the communities remain motorable and can access the market centres from the farmlands.  

https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157651399061636/
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
We started using in Cabinet today our new eCabinet platform. The introduction of full technology and its deployment in Cabinet will enhance our work in a paperless environment, allow Ministers to have access to information and documents in real time, and be able to access them. It is a good start today, and I look forward to all members of Cabinet getting abreast with the platform and its functionalities in good time.  
http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/868

President Idriss Déby Itno of Chad and I held very fruitful discussions on Wednesday and agreed to the hosting of a Joint Summit of leaders of Central and West African states next month. That will be a historic Summit and will be an opportunity for us to firm up a common strategy to combat the Boko Haram insurgency. 

A communique released after our meeting is available here- http://presidency.gov.gh/ghanachad.pdf and you can also access photographs of the visit from this link- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649098322744/.

Message:
Earlier today, Tuesday, I hosted our gallant young Black Stars and their technical handlers to breakfast where I expressed the appreciation of the good people of Ghana to them. They worked hard to redeem themselves at the AFCON 2015 after their disappointing and poor display at the Brazil World Cup. On behalf of their headline sponsor, GNPC, I also announced a $25,000 bonus for each player from their sponsor. 

Click here for audio: https://soundcloud.com/flagstaffhouse/president-mahama-welcomes-the-black-stars

Click for photos: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157648415613764/
President JD Mahama's post-match tweet, congratulating the Black Stars for a good tournament.

"With determination, discipline, dedication to duty, fortitude and patriotism, you shall emerge victorious."
--- President JD Mahama, in a goodwill message to the Black Stars ahead of their 2015 AFCON Final Match against La Cote d'Ivoire.

"In the African tradition, if anything happens in your brother's house you have to go and visit and make sure that things are okay, and that is why I came. You also know that our ECOWAS protocols do not support violent overthrow of governments, so we want to remind all member states of the protocols that ECOWAS has, that change of government must be through democratic means and as far as possible we should try and abide by that." 
--- H.E. John Dramani Mahama, Chair of the ECOWAS Authority of Heads of State & Government. He was speaking to journalists on Sunday after a short but important visit to The Gambia to express, on behalf of ECOWAS, solidarity with the President, Government and People of the country following a failed attempt at a coup d'etat. 

Photos of the Gambian visit are available at: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157650068747440/

"Finally, we also discussed the issue of international crisis management. Chancellor Merkel has invited Ghana to join Germany and Norway to sponsor a special request to the UN Secretary General to conduct a critical study of the world’s international crisis management response especially in the area of health so that we are not taken by surprise again like it happened when the Ebola outbreak happened. As President of Ghana I have agreed to join Germany and Norway to sponsor the request."
--- President John Dramani Mahama speaking a press conference in Berlin after a meeting with German Chancellor Dr. Angela Merkel.

At a Grand Durbar in Yendi to round-off the Damba Festival of the Chiefs and People of Dagbon, President John Mahama who has been working both with the Otumfuo Committee of Eminent Persons and through personal meetings to resolve the outstanding issues in Dagbon, was enskined and decorated as Zoomalgu Naa (Chief of Reconciliation) of Dagbon. The title was conferred on him by the regent of Dagbon at the end of Saturday's durbar which was attended by both gates of the Dagbon Skin.

At the inauguration of Her Excellency Dilma Rousseff on Thursday for her second term as President of the Federative Republic of Brazil.

Click for more photos: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649654960568/

First Lady, Lordina Mahama, joins the children of Bole in a singing session during a Children's Christmas Party in the President's home town. President John Mahama and his family spent the Christmas Holiday in Bole, and in addition to the children's party also interacted with the traditional and opinion leaders in the town. 

Click for some more photos from the party.

Message: NA

"Our only focus as a party, and a social democratic party, is to improve the lives of our people. I am glad to observe that notwithstanding the temporary challenges that we are facing, your party is making remarkable progress in many sectors of our national life and let nobody tell you anything different. The achievements are there to see in all sectors of national life."
-- President John Mahama addressing delegates to the NDC's 8th National Delegates Congress in Kumasi. 

Click to view photos-- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649867617611/

Click to read the President's speech to delegates at the Congress--http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/771

story: John Dramani Mahama shared a link.

Message: Today, I joined President Uhuru Kenyatta and the good people of Kenya at the Nyayo National Stadium for their 51st Jamhuri Day Celebrations. It was a colourful and cultural ceremony, and in my solidarity message I recounted the strong bond of friendship between our two countries.

I look forward to joining my brother, President Uhuru Kenyatta, and the people of Kenya at their 51st Independence Day Celebrations tomorrow. We will also be holding discussions that will focus on the African Renaissance and improving intra African trade. This State Visit has been rescheduled a few times and I am happy to be in Nairobi to reaffirm the brotherly relations between Kwame Nkrumah's Ghana and Jomo's Kenya. 
 
https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649716807615/

President John Mahama, leader of the ruling National Democratic Congress (NDC) has extended well wishes to all persons vying for various executive positions in the party. 

The NDC will climax its election of executives for a new term on December 20, 2014 in Kumasi. President Mahama asked contestants, in a statement, to continue to engage in a campaign of ideas and strategies. 

He noted that, “your prime objective should be how to make the NDC, which is the only party that truly cares for the people of Ghana and continues to demonstrate that through its policies and actions, stronger and more formidable.”

The statement also urged delegates to the December 20 Congress to ignore any claims by any of the candidates that “he/she is my choice or my preferred person, because there is none.”

“Vote for whoever you believe has the capacity and ability to help grow our great party and work with the millions of supporters across the country. As President and Leader, it is who you, the delegates, decide on that I will work with”, the statement ended.

Today at Sefwi Wiawso, I joined our gallant farmers and fishers for the 2014 National Farmers Day awards ceremony. In all our regions and districts, similar award ceremonies were held. 

Congratulations to the National Best Farmer for year, George Asamoah Amankwah of Europa Farms. The 49-year old has been farming for 17 years and has 129 acres of maize, 6,800 acres plantation farm, 20 acres of pepper and okra farms, plantain intercrop of 6000 acres, 25,000 mounds of yam, 20 acres of oil farm, 147 cattle and three fish ponds with catfish and tilapia. 

I say ayekoo to all our farmers and fishers throughout the country. 

https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649213638858/

President John Mahama started a 3-day State Visit to Doha today with a meeting with the Emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani, at the Emiri Diwan Palace.  

The meeting, which was held behind closed doors focussed on improving relations between the two countries and the President's quest for major investments in the country's power sector in furtherance of his vision to develop Ghana into a power hub in West Africa. 

On arrival at the Emiri Diwan Palace, President Mahama inspected a Guard of Honour mounted by the Royal Guards after the two leaders took the national salute. 

Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani also hosted President Mahama and his delegation to a Royal Lunch as part of the three-day State Visit by the President. 

Please click for photos: https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157649537771645/

President John Dramani Mahama, in his capacity as Chair of the ECOWAS Authority of Heads of State and Government, will this morning be in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso to meet all the stakeholders in that country. 

The visit follows the receipt of a report from a Joint Mission of ECOWAS, the African Union and the United Nations that was sent to Burkina Faso. The Mission, which was in that country from October 30, returned to brief President Mahama last Sunday, before returning to Ouagadougou on Monday. 

President Mahama approved the recommendations of the Joint Mission and reaffirmed the subregional group, ECOWAS' support for a peaceful restoration of constitutional order. He has also been engaging with the stakeholders including the military and called for a consensual solution in line with the provisions of the constitution of Burkina Faso. 

President Mahama has invited two of his colleagues, President Macky Sall of Senegal and President Goodluck Jonathan of Nigeria to join him on the Mission to Burkina Faso today. 

ECOWAS has assured Burkina Faso of its readiness to work with them to restore legitimate transitional order and finding sustainable solutions to the impasse and work towards organizing free and credible elections. 

President Mahama will return home later today.
President Mahama meets His Majesty King Harald V of Norway

As part of his 4-day Official Visit to the Kingdom of Norway, President John Mahama attended a seminar on the 'Norwegian Model', a session to learn more about the Norwegian welfare state and organized social dialogue. Photo below shows President Mahama sharing his views after the presentations by three resource persons. Other photos from the Official Visit to the Kingdom of Norway are also available on the flickr page.

President John Dramani Mahama this morning held bilateral talks with the Norwegian Prime Minister, Ms. Erna Solberg at her Official Residence in Oslo.

Mr. Mahama is on a 4-day Official Visit at the invitation of the Prime Minister. Later today, the President will participate in a seminar on the development of Ghana's renewable energy sector, learning from the Norwegian example. 

President Mahama will also hold talks with the King of Norway at the Royal Palace and participate in a Norwegian- African Business Association Conference.

Congratulations, President Dilma Rousseff, on a well fought election. 
We hope to continue our work in strengthening further, the cooperation between Ghana and Brazil. 

-- President John Mahama 
Monday October 27, 2014.

As part of his Official Visit to the United Kingdom, President John Dramani Mahama and his wife, Lordina, on Thursday visited the Buckingham Palace for a private meeting with Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II. President Mahama and the Queen discussed a number of issues of common interest to the two countries, while the Queen was interested in the First Lady's health-related activities and humanitarian support. President Mahama presented the Queen with a copy of his first book, My First Coup D'etat And Other True Stories from the Lost Decades of Africa.
story: John Dramani Mahama added 3 new photos.

Message:
President John Mahama, early this morning, arrived in London for a number of engagements including a presentation to the All Party Parliamentary Group. He will also attend and address a number of investment forums and open The Global African Investment Forum on Monday. 

Mr. Mahama will also lead various roundtable discussions in investment in Ghana and Africa and pay a courtesy call on the Queen at the Buckingham Palace. Click link for details of the President's visit- http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/700

Click for photos of President Mahama's arrival- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157648843054051/

Shortly after reviewing the 2014 Graduation Parade of the Ghana Military Academy in Accra on Friday, President John Dramani Mahama flew to Abuja, Nigeria for talks with President Goodluck Ebele Jonathan. 

The discussions centered around three issues- the security situation in the sub-region and Boko Haram, the Ebola Disease Virus, and the irregular supply of gas by the West African Gas Pipeline project. 

President Mahama also used the opportunity to thank President Jonathan, his Government and the People of Nigeria for making available one of their transporter planes to airlift humanitarian aid to the three countries. A total of 3,000 bags of Ghanaian-grown white long grain rice, 300 cartons each of Made in Ghana cooking oil, cocoa products and milk were airlifted to support the three countries.  

See more photos from Aso Rock, Nigeria here.- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157648824101462/

President John Mahama today, Thursday, spent the 2014 World Food Day with the farming community of Branam in the Brong Ahafo Region where the United Conglomerate Farms is cultivating a 623 acre maize farm. The target, according to the Farm Managers, is a 1,000 acres, and they are looking with the support of the chiefs and people to cultivate other crops on the 10,000 acres released by the chiefs to the company. Adjacent to this farm, the National Service Scheme also has a 100-acre farm on the previous State Farms Land. 

President Mahama, a son of a rice farmer and a farmer himself, stunned everybody when he went on a tour of the farm driving a farm tractor and explaining the processes to the audience. 

Click below for more photographs from the President's World Food Day visit to the Branam Farming Community- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157648794982452/

"I want to thank you because cocoa continues to be the mainstay of this economy. Every year we earn anything close to US$3billion on cocoa alone and yet people are more excited about oil. Ghana has discovered oil so our lives are going to change. Cocoa still affects our lives more than oil. The contribution of oil to our national budget last year was only US$700million. Cocoa brought US$3billion into our economy. So cocoa is still the mainstay of our economy and we must put our money where our mouths are, and we must continue to put our money in cocoa farming so that it can continue to sustain this economy" 
-- President Mahama speaking at the Flagstaff House on Wednesday when a large delegation of cocoa farmers called on him to thank him for the 62.74% increase in the producer price of cocoa. 

Click here for photos and below for the full remarks of the President- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/15294071098/

http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/693

Work has started on the $100 million Upgrading and Expansion of the Tamale Airport into an International Airport. To be completed next year, the new airport is expected, among others, to help reduce air traffic to and from the Kotoka International Airport. 
The start of the project is in fulfillment of a 2008 Campaign Promise by the late, President John Evans Atta Mills in Tamale. Before breaking the ground for the start of the project, President John Mahama said the upgrading of the Tamale airport will boost commercial farming and exports from the Northern parts of the country and also enhance tourism arrivals, among others. The first phase of the project comprises the extension of the runway to 3,940 meters and expanded to accommodate wide bodied aircrafts and installation of a complete lighting system. 
Click here for photos... https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157647428169412/

As part of my visit to the Central Region on Saturday, I went back to the Cape Coast Stadium under construction, and I am fulfilled that the new sporting edifice will be ready by August next year for use. The volume of work done since my last inspection a few months ago, is appreciable, and I am informed that 49% of the works has been completed. We are also ready to relocate our sisters and mothers to the temporal market stalls for work to start on the construction of a new and modern market at Kotokuraba. 

Click for more photos from the two visits- https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157646909242987/
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
President John Mahama inspecting the Made in Ghana label of a sports wear manufactured in Ghana for export to the USA by Dignity DTRT Limited. 

"This is the first in a series of visits I am making to Ghanaian companies that are producing Made in Ghana goods", the President stated, promising that in line with his structural transformation (of the economy) agenda, government will support the garments/ textile industry, which has a potential to employs thousands of people, just as it is doing for other sectors including pharmaceutical, poultry and agriculture in general. Click for more photos of his visit to the factory floor of the garment manufacturer. https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157646865327949/

Today, Saturday, President Mahama will visit another Made in Ghana company, a Bamboo Factory in Assin Fosu.

"The important thing about this gas is that it allows us to have energy security in terms of putting in more thermal production and it fits into our programme of turning Ghana into the energy hub of West Africa both to provide enough to feed our own demand which is growing very fast, but if we have extra power to be able to export it and earn foreign currency as a power exporter. So those prospects all look very good, it ties into my vision of increasing our power production to 5,000MW over the next few years. And I believe that once all these contracts are signed this year, all the companies that we have signed Memorandum of Understandings with for installation of IPP thermal plants will feel secure to go ahead because they know that by the time they finish their thermal projects, gas will be available to power those projects."--- President John Mahama speaking during a visit to the Gas Processing Plant site at Atuabo in the Western Region on Tuesday September 02, 2014. 
https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157647164466142/

President John Mahama today joined the people of Akoto Lante and Nima- Maamobi, both in the Greater Accra Region, to help whip up the communal spirit and community clean-up exercises to help clear the filth in our communities. Government he said will support the institution of once-a-month clean up exercises in all communities activated and supervised by the MMDAs, adding that all shops must close on those days to support the exercise. 

President Mahama who was accompanied by his Chief of Staff and other officials, joined in the clean-up exercise and also visited the La General and LEKMA Hospitals where he was briefed on the cholera situation and also presented quantities of assorted fruits to in-patients. 

Click for a link to more photos of the President's Saturday Clean Up Exercise. https://www.flickr.com/photos/fhcommsbureau/sets/72157646632084088/
NA
story: John Dramani Mahama updated their cover photo.

Message:
In one of the many interviews I granted during the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit in Washington, I explained yet again that Ghana has not gone to the IMF for a loan or what many claim is a bail out. 

“We are not looking for a bailout”, I explained to Bloomberg TV.

In the Treaty Room of the U.S. State Department on Tuesday, where Finance Minister Seth Terkper signed, on behalf of Ghana, a new Compact Agreement with the U.S. Government's Millennium Challenge Corporation. The $498 million compact represents the largest U.S. Government transaction to date under the Obama Administration’s Power Africa initiative. As I stated before the signing, "the objective of this new compact is to reduce poverty through economic growth in Ghana with direct interventions in the energy sector. This will not only enhance our own efforts at improving the sector, but would hopefully accelerate it."

Lordina and I shared a photo opportunity with President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama in the Blue Room of the White House. This was shortly after arriving for a dinner hosted by the Obama's for all leaders attending the U.S.-Africa Leaders Summit.

We have had to approve strong but unpleasant measures to increase revenue and reduce expenditures. While these measures have been a bitter pill, the alternative of doing nothing would have caused an economic meltdown and even more suffering for our people. As a people we have had to make sacrifices and I wish to assure you all that the results would begin to show very soon. As I said on May Day, ‘the darkest hour is before the break of a new dawn’.

I salute the adoption of the Ghana Infrastructure Investment Fund Bill. I initiated this Fund to tackle the annual infrastructure deficit of about US$1.5 billion and to create more stable jobs for our people. The Ghana Infrastructure Investment Fund will pursue its own ratings on the domestic and international financial and capital markets. In order to support our economy's continued growth and also reach the infrastructure levels of a middle-income country, the Fund will partner the private sector to finance critical infrastructure projects.
NA
story: John Dramani Mahama updated their cover photo.

Message: A rare stable democracy in Africa, Ghana may be just what Africa needs to produce regional leaders able to address issues from terrorism to infectious disease.
NA
story: John Dramani Mahama updated their profile picture.

Message: I wish to call on all member states of ECOWAS, particularly border officials, to take all the legal and necessary steps to remove all challenges or bottlenecks to trade and commercial activities within our region. Some of our business men and women complain that in addition to paying all the relevant duties and levies, they are still confronted with situations and hindrances that often make it prohibitive for them to do business within our sub-region. Some of these obstacles are the multiplicity of legal and illegal checkpoints and barriers, lengthy inspection times and documentation requirements, plus costly delays - regardless of whether documentation is complete or not. Many businesspeople of West Africa have been frustrated by the request for substantial informal payments at borders, in addition to the regulatory registration requirements and high costs of transit fees demanded by our Member States. These are some of the problems that undermine the competiveness of our products while the high cost of production constitutes a disincentive for doing business in the region.

Patriotism also implies supporting local industries, patronizing things produced here. Take the message of the "Made-in-Ghana" campaign and spread it all over our country. That means helping our brothers and sisters who have businesses, encouraging others to start new ones and, above all, believing in the future of our nation.

Here is an excerpt from my speech at the National Prayer and Thanksgiving Service: In the Bible, there are many instances in which nations have brought supplications to the Almighty God, in times of tribulation and crisis. There are many occasions during which we – as a nation, Ghana – have called on God in times of crisis, and He has listened to us. We have been through periods of economic challenges. We have been through periods of drought and hunger. And in all these periods God has listened to us and has delivered us. Indeed, God has been good to us. We have natural resources. We have talented people. We have a beautiful environment. We have political stability. And above all, we have peace. What probably is lacking – and for which we pray that God grants us - is a singleness of purpose, a unity of mind and a oneness of our hearts. It is only with singleness of purpose and oneness of heart and working together that we can make progress as a nation. Let us eschew pessimism. We must count our blessings and our successes. And we must continuously ask God, “Why are we so blessed?” It is only with such a positive frame of mind that we can overcome any challenges facing us. God has blessed us with peace, and we cannot take this for granted.

I salute the adoption of the National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (2012-2020), which I had the privilege of commissioning while I was still the Vice President. I call upon the media, the religious organizations, traditional leaders and our entire Ghanaian people to use this new instrument and tackle the canker of corruption. Government has and will prove the political will to implement this Plan and will ensure the adequate funding of the institutions involved in fighting corruption.

I made a promise to work in partnership with you, the citizens of this country. I have not forgotten that promise; nor have I forgotten that one of the greatest virtues of leadership is the ability to listen. I want to assure the good citizens of our great nation, the farmers, fishermen, traders, workers, students, security personnel and all ‘concerned citizens’ that I am listening and that I will continue to listen. We all have a stake in the destiny of our nation and irrespective of our ethnic origin, gender or political affiliation, we can work together to make our nation great and strong.

Republic Day is the day on which we pay tribute to the Senior Citizens in our society, those individuals who helped build this great nation of ours. Our own history has shown us, as exemplified in a speech of Dr. Nkrumah’s, that it is in actuality the "asking", the "demanding", which spurs into action that very motion of destiny. And our Senior Citizens are the ones whose labour and values, whose dreams and demands shaped that destiny—and for this alone, we owe them a debt of gratitude. So on behalf of all Ghanaians, I say, "thank you" and "Ayekooo".http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/608

I congratulate the Black Stars for the talent, effort and teamwork that they displayed during each of their three matches. I also congratulate all Ghanaians, at home and in the Diaspora, for your unwavering support of our national team. Even now, with the knowledge that our team has been eliminated, we still feel that World Cup victory is possible for the Black Stars, just not this year, not this time. So we are going to rebuild our team. They will become even stronger, even faster… and next time, next time, see how our Black Stars will shine and dance their way, one goal after another, straight into the World Cup finals. It is possible. We must believe.

President John Dramani Mahama has been elected Chairperson of the African Union’s High Level African Trade Committee (HATC). The Committee’s main responsibility is the unlocking of blockages in the implementation of the framework, road map and architecture for the establishment of the Continental Free Trade Area (CFTA). President Mahama has been a personal advocate for improved intra-African trade and is expected to use his tenure to push the agenda for greater trade among countries on the continent.

This is a perfect example for the purpose of the "Made-in-Ghana" campaign. CNN presents a Ghanaian factory, with Ghanaian workers, owner and management, which meets international quality standards and has become a landmark in agricultural business. God gave Ghana the rich lands, but it depends on us to sow, grow and harvest what we need and furthermore.
http://edition.cnn.com/video/data/2.0/video/international/2014/06/23/spc-african-voices-seth-dei-b.cnn.html

Ghana has achieved sufficiency in maize, yam and cassava production, so government would increase investment on the production of rice, sugar, poultry and tomatoes, in order to reduce imports and our country's dependency level.  Government would also identify young people interested in agriculture and support small-scale farmer groups with technical assistance. We want the youth to understand that agriculture is not only for the elderly and that farming is a rewarding business.

Exactly a year ago, our total power consumption was 1,670 megawatts. One year on, this has jumped to 1,920 megawatts. This means we should be adding more than 200 megawatts of power every year to be able to match up to the demand. In this respect, our government would strengthen relations with countries like the Netherlands that has the expertise in renewable energy.The Netherlands has enormous experience in green technology, which Ghana will be ready to tap into for the generation of more power in the following years.

Let us not be discouraged by this supposed defeat. Let us, rather, focus on the strength of the will and talent displayed during this game. Let us throw the full weight of our support behind our national team. Let us keep facing forward. http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/591

The Black Stars have always gone out into the world and carried the message of unity and African pride. What they have taught us and continue to teach us as a nation is what truly makes a star shine; even in the midst of all the darkness that surrounds it, it still puts forth everything it has got to give. May God bless our Black Stars.
http://graphic.com.gh/features/opinion/25204-how-we-shine.html

Ghana has such a huge potential in shrimp farming, that this sector could create about 200,000 jobs within five years and fetch our economy about $2 billion annually. The government intends collaborating with Vietnam to help aquaculture in our country and to make fish farming attractive to the youth. Ghana can become a major producer of fish so I encourage especially the young graduates in Agriculture to establish their own farms.

Government is working on a community improvement project aimed at improving the living conditions in our Zongo communities. President Mahama, at a meeting with the National Chief Imam and the Council of Muslim Chiefs, said the project, which is being undertaken in collaboration with the Brazilian government, consists of building and developing roads, housing and drains. Government will also liaise with the Council of Muslim Chiefs to come up with training programmes for the Zongo youth.

In many of our ECOWAS countries, the fruits of accelerated economic growth are not being spread equitably amongst our people. This is a powder keg with a potential to threaten the peace and security of our sub-region. As such, ECOWAS must play a leading role in the effort to fully restore peace and security to the sub region and by so doing, safeguard our future and all of the work that we have done to ensure that our nations are prosperous.

I called a one-day Extraordinary Session for leaders of the ECOWAS member-states. Tomorrow we will discuss issues of urgent concern, including the security situations in Northern Mali and parts of Nigeria. We also have to enhance regional cooperation and set the pace for African integration.

The Government of Ghana is committed to the process of rooting out corruption from our system. As part of this process, Government will provide the necessary funds to the anti-corruption institutions. The passage of the pending constitutional review will help the set- up of the "Democracy Fund", which will help improve resourcing of our anti-corruption agencies. We have within us the power to expose corruption on all levels that it may occur, and to demand transparency and accountability from our elected representatives.

After meeting with the United Arab Emirates Deputy Minister for Economic Affairs, I am pleased to tell you that we have secured a $100million grant from the UAE for infrastructure projects. Besides this grant, we have agreed that our partners from Abu Dhabi National Energy Company (TAQA) will build a new 350MW combined cycle power plant that will also produce 100,000 cubic liters of desalinated water. The first 100 MW will be ready in 12 months.

We need a better collaboration between industry and academia, in order to enable graduates to fit into the job market. A necessary intervention is required from the business leaders: they have to let the educational institutions know the skills and areas they need, so the curricula can be aligned to suit the demand. Another intervention has to come from the government and we are committed to address the issue of graduate unemployment.

The sudden death of my Senior Adviser and Mentor, Mr. Paul Victor Obeng, has left us in a state of shock and disbelief. At this moment, my deepest condolences and sympathies are with his widow, Mrs. Rose Obeng, and all members of his family. I will miss him dearly.

I am satisfied with the outcome of the National Economic Forum and I am impressed at the zeal and enthusiasm the stakeholders have shown over these last three days. The solutions in the Senchi Consensus are very far reaching and the government will take the necessary steps to immediately implement this agreement. This is a new day for Ghana, one that we are together shaping as a nation.
http://www.johnmahama.org/news/the-senchi-consensus-full-text

The introduction of EnviroDome marked the beginning of Ghana’s revolution towards a position of net exporter of vegetables. The government will support the use of EnviroDome programme with our utmost commitment and effort to make sure that it succeeds to ensure food sufficiency and create job opportunities.

The decision to intervene in the affairs of a sovereign nation is a delicate one. After a series of almost back-to-back violent attacks and other acts of aggression by the Boko Haram terrorist group, it became obvious that the situation would require an effort greater than any one nation could tackle alone.

I wish to state, with great emphasis, that as President I have not taken any decision to enter our country into an IMF programme. What we are concentrating on is the preparation of a homegrown strategy of fiscal consolidation. The briefs that were presented to Parliament and then later to the IMF represent work in progress and would be finalized through broad consultations, such as the forum we are holding today.

It is a tragedy that such a simple misunderstanding of the relevance of this innocuous document should become the basis for a major political player to stay away from this all-important national exercise.

Here is my Opening Address at the National Economic Forum.
http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/555

On behalf of the ECOWAS heads of state, I express our solidarity with the government and people of Nigeria in the face of the terrorist attacks. As Chair of ECOWAS, I have been speaking with other heads of state and they believe that we should activate the Common Anti-Terrorism strategy. We are looking to call a meeting of our joint intelligence chiefs in Accra next week and we are inviting Cameroun and Chad to join, so that together we can see how we eliminate this security threat to the sub-region.

The world has been slow in its outrage towards the abduction of more than 200 Nigerian girls. Is it because they are poor? Is it because they are African? The international community must help Nigeria to fight terrorism and bring back the girls. They are our girls.                                                                        
Here is the text I have written for Ebony magazine.

I salute the new energy project that has been launched in Ghana. Assisted by the Ministry of Energy and Petroleum, the multinational conglomerate General Electric, the world's 4th biggest public company, has signed with two private partners a joint development agreement meant to add 1000 megawatts of electricity to Ghana's national grid. The project consists of building an integrated gas-to-power thermal plant and a regasification unit in the next 5 years and would create hundreds of new jobs for our people. It proves once more that our stable and democratic country is a very attractive environment for foreign investment that helps boosting our economy.
NA
story: John Dramani Mahama updated their cover photo.

Message: I have directed the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the Ministry of Education to roll out a new social programme to provide school children in deprived communities with free sandals. This programme and the new orders from the security agencies will enable the Defence Industrial Holding Company in Kumasi, which I visited last week, to employ more young people.

Last month I took an inventory of my household to find out how many Made-in-Ghana goods we were using. Recently I have pooled together data for another inventory, on the amount of money that we, as a nation, are spending on basic food items. The result, which I am now sharing, is alarming. It is time to make real changes, for the good of our beloved Ghana. (Click on the link below to see how much money we are spending on the importation of some basic items.)
http://graphic.com.gh/features/opinion/22123-what-you-don-t-know.html

Fellow Ghanaians, below is an excerpt from my address earlier today at the Black Star Square where we marked the 2014 May Day. W can only be in this together and appreciate the various dynamics of our national development. 

"As a social democrat, I have the utmost respect for the right of our gallant workers to negotiate a living wage.  But as President, I have an obligation, too, to the rest of our population to ensure that the economy of this country is protected. I have an obligation to ensure that there are enough resources left over to enable that the other 24.4 million Ghanaians who are not public sector workers have access to quality healthcare, education, clean drinking water, adequate sanitation, power, and the numerous other commitments the state is obliged to provide, especially if we are to continue making positive changes in the social indicators that reflect our progress and development."

Yesterday I commissioned the Vessel Traffic Management Information System (VTMIS), which ensures full electronic surveillance of the coast of Ghana. The VTMIS will enhance security and safety of Ghana's maritime domain and will improve search and rescue operations. This system has come at an opportune time when Ghana has recently joined the group of oil producing countries. Ghana’s economic and political stability makes her the gateway to Africa as well as rapidly becoming a maritime trading hub for West and Central Africa.

There is no reason why we have hectares of arable land good for rice growing and yet we have to import $400m worth of rice every year. We have land for sugarcane, yet import nearly $200m worth of sugar a year. We're going to target seven crops and if we put in the right investment we should reduce drastically the billions we spend importing these items. Here is the whole interview I had with The Africa Report. http://www.theafricareport.com/West-Africa/ghana-we-are-listening-to-business-john-mahama.html

I am happy that the two-day summit organized by the ECOWAS Parliament in Accra focused on the issue of free movement of people and goods in the sub-region. As a grouping, we have agreed to implement some new initiatives, including the single border crossing point between countries. This will reduce the many hurdles our people face when they travel from one country to another.

My dear Ghanaians, brothers and sisters

Every year, when Easter comes, I think of the unique power of sacrifice. As fragile and useless it may seem sacrifice proves to be, over and over again, mankind's most powerful engine. Good parents sacrifice their present comfort for the future of their children. Real friends devote precious time and support to the ones they feel attached to. True heroes give their blood and endure humiliation for the sake of an idea or maybe for the birth of a nation.

Our Lord Jesus Christ sacrificed His life for all of us. He suffered atrocious torture for the future of all His children. He gave up His human time for our chance to eternity. He went to hell so we can all go to heaven.

This is love. This is the greatest love in our world history. We have a sacred example that we can follow and Easter tells us how magnificent the power of love is.

So, for this wonderful celebration, I want to tell you this, my dear Ghanaians: let's fight the selfishness in our minds. Let's help, as much as we can, the poor and the ill. Let's have patience with our children and play with them until they grow mature. Let's take care of our old parents and grandparents and remember that only their bodies age, not their souls. Let's work not only for tomorrow and not only for ourselves, but for our communities and our great country.

Let's love more.

I wish you all a Happy Easter! May God give you and your families warm hearts and understanding!

Please read the article below. Yes, most of our people cannot afford to buy such shoes, but these are the spirit and the initiative I am looking for in the "Made-in-Ghana" campaign. This story is not the only example of the entrepreneurial energy in Ghana. 
http://edition.cnn.com/2014/04/09/business/made-in-ghana-high-end-shoes/index.html#cnn-disqus-area

Our Cabinet has approved the Petroleum Exploration and Production Bill, which will ensure efficient exploitation of our national resources. The petroleum revenue is one of the major engines for our country's development, so the present laws have to be changed in order to tackle all the emerging issues in this key economic sector.

After discussions with the Economic Management Team, we have concluded that our country will benefit from a National Forum on the Economy. More information about the forum will be provided soon. We are convinced that the passion involved in the present bipartisan debate leads to inefficiency. Economic difficulties can be better tackled through brainstorming, by gathering all the stakeholders (political parties, civil society, private sector, labour and government) around the same table. One of my duties, as a President, is to aim for social peace and secure a national consensus on the critical issues.

If the Arab Spring has taught us anything, it is that, it is no longer acceptable to be ambivalent about the needs of the poor and marginalized in our societies – especially in our expanding and unequal cities. In the next two decades, even cities with limited resources shall experience explosions of urban growth. This means that implementing innovative concepts of urban development corridors and mega-urban regions is no longer a question of “if”, but when.
Our young people should be the main beneficiaries of the Made-in-Ghana campaign. Here are some places where they can turn their enthusiasm and creativity into entrepreneurship.

I have taken an inventory of my home to find out how many Made-in-Ghana products I use on a daily basis. Here is my list. Take your own inventory. What are the imported items in your house that could have been made in Ghana?
http://www.johnmahama.org/blog-john-dramani-mahama/quot-made-in-ghana-quot-products-i-used-on-a-daily-basis&page=1

President John Dramani Mahama has held separate meetings with German Chancellor Angela Merkel, President Francois Hollande of France, President of the EU Commission, José Manuel Barroso, British Foreign Secretary William Hague, Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy Brey and the Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Mark Rutte,  on the margins of the 4th EU-Africa Summit in Brussels, Belgium. The bilateral discussions centred largely around President Mahama’s new role as the Chair of the Economic Community of West African States, (ECOWAS), investment opportunities in Ghana and the Economic Partnership Agreement (EPA) between the EU and ECOWAS.
story: John Dramani Mahama added 5 new photos to the album: President John Mahama at the 4th EU-Africa Summit.

Message: West Africa possesses the resources to build a decent and dignified life for every one of our people. Extensive natural resources, educated and skilled human resources, rich arable lands, all represent opportunities for creating a prosperous future for our people. What we need is partnerships with our friends so that we can take full and proper advantage of these opportunities.
Here is a transcript of President Mahama's remarks on Tuesday at a high level panel on fragile states organized as part of the 4th EU-Africa Summit in Brussels.

I am deeply humbled by the decision of the Presidents and Heads of State from West Africa to elect me as the new Chair of ECOWAS. I take this as an honor to the people of my beloved Ghana and, on their behalf, I will faithfully serve the people of our entire West African subregion. We have come very far in the quest to unite our people, but we have to speed up and deliver the prosperity they deserve. In line with this goal, we have to reject every effort to divide us and achieve true integration, so that our subregion would lead the way for the whole African continent.
http://www.presidency.gov.gh/node/511
President John Dramani Mahama has been elected unanimously as the new Chair of the ECOWAS Authority of Heads of State and Government for a one year term.
story: John Dramani Mahama added 3 new photos to the album: President John Dramani Mahama is the new Chair of the ECOWAS.

Message: I publicly thank the members of the Advisory Committee drafted to work on the Ghana Infrastructure Investment Fund. The committee was inaugurated on 28th January and promised to deliver a report in a period of four months. They delivered the report yesterday, in less than two months, and moreover, the committee has worked without taking any allowances. Ghanaians have grown tired with committees that meet up endlessly and take allowances, but the members of this committee understand that our country is in a hurry. So their performance should be held up as a model of public service and patriotism.

The Cabinet will soon approve the amendment to the Constitution submitted by the Constitutional Review Implementation Commission. One of the major changes refers to a provision of the 1992 Constitution which says that the President, the Vice-President, the Speaker of Parliament, the justices of the Supreme Court, the members of the Council of State, the Ministers and the Members of Parliament are exempted from paying taxes. This is completely unfair and my government has decided to change it. All Ghanaian citizens should be equals in front of the law. The President together with all the public office holders must set the example and be the first to pay their taxes.

Good news for our country's aim of becoming the preferred destination for maritime business in West Africa: the Ghana Maritime Authority has completed a project that provides full surveillance of our territorial waters. This makes Ghana one of the few countries in Africa that can monitor all the vessels moving in and out of its maritime domain. The incidence of terrorist acts is rising, so this new monitoring system will ensure the safety of people and cargo in the Gulf of Guinea.

Do you need access to clean water at home? Electricity? Are the streets in your area unpaved? Is the nearest hospital still too far? Do you dream of the day an official will come and ask how is your life? If the answer to any of these questions is "Yes", join this platform and tell your local administration it has a duty to yourself and your family.Click on the picture below!

The Public-Private Partnership between Ghana Ports & Harbours Authority and Meridian Port Services is one of the finest models of PPP that we have in our country. Yesterday I inaugurated nine new gentry cranes at the Tema Port, an investment of nearly US$50million which will further improve the efficieny of this terminal. Using the same PPP, we want to soon see the start of the biggest expansion that Tema Port has ever experienced. It is estimated to cost between US$600 million and US$ 1 billion and, when achieved, it will make Tema the biggest and most efficient port not only in West Africa but probably in the whole of Africa.
story: John Dramani Mahama added 3 new photos.

Message: The road engineers are working around the clock to repair the damaged bridge on the Tema Motorway. Yesterday I ordered the immediate re-opening of one lane to reduce the congestion. A temporary route is to be completed within one week and the whole bridge would be fixed within five weeks. I thank all the motorists and passengers for their patience.
story: John Dramani Mahama added 2 new photos.

Message:
Why did I make a call to increase your patronage of Made-in-Ghana goods? Because this idea has stirred such debates, I think it deserves further explanations.
http://www.johnmahama.org/blog-john-dramani-mahama/made-in-ghana-challenging-our-national-spirit

I asked the heads of churches to participate fully in efforts to transform the Ghanaian economy, reminding them that, as leaders of various congregations, they must contribute to changing the mindset of Ghanaians to go for items production.
NA
story: John Dramani Mahama updated their cover photo.

Message:
I told the people of the Western Region, during my three-day visit, that Ghana cannot develop thoroughly having only one growth pole, the Accra-Tema business district. We need more growth poles, in Ashanti, Eastern Region, Volta Region and, of course, Western Region has to become a significant growth pole. This way, when people wish to migrate, they could head towards this region to seek opportunities.

We will continue the main projects - the expansion of the Takoradi port, building the Takoradi-Kumasi road and the Dunkwa-Awaso railway line. Moreover, the goal of our government for the Western Region is to build there an alumina industry. Because we sell a tonne of raw bauxite with $40, while the market value of alumina is almost 10 times higher.

So I want to tell you once more: we must restructure and diversify our economy, otherwise we will continue to be affected by any fall in the cocoa or gold prices. Building a modern economy, adding value to our products, means new jobs for our youth, a stronger country and a good future for our children.
Corruption hurts society as a whole, so we must fight it as a whole. I call upon you all to assist in the fight against corruption as a patriotic duty.

I spoke about inflation, oil revenues and changing Ghana in this interview with CNN.
http://edition.cnn.com/video/data/2.0/video/world/2014/03/11/intv-newton-john-dramani-mahama-oil-ghana.cnn.html

Message:
President Mahama has initiated the campaign “Buy Made in Ghana” to encourage Ghanaians to patronize local products. His Excellency announced concrete measures: 

-A new sugar processing plant in Komenda to support the demand locally and reduce the level of imports.
-An agreement between the Tema Oil Refinery and Petro Saudi which to revamp operations of the refinery which in turn would reduce the foreign exchange problems facing the country.
-Strategic partnerships to produce Jute Sacks which is currently imported.
-Mr. President requested the Electricity Company of Ghana to encourage the production of electrical materials locally.

President John Dramani Mahama is in Parliament delivering the State of the Nation Address. His Excellency is very concerned about the challenges facing Ghanaians – especially recent issues with water, electricity and tariffs. Here are some talking points and messages: 

Energy: Compared to this same time last year, the electricity or energy situation is much better. It is not fully resolved yet, but we need to acknowledge that we have come a very long way. In fact Ghana’s electricity connectivity is among the best in Africa – probably only second to South Africa and/or Morocco.  Still, President Mahama is driving all the relevant officials and government entities to deliver on his objective to give energy security to Ghanaians.

Jobs: The President is very focused on creating jobs. He believes that when energy or electricity is stable then there would be a cascading effect in terms of private enterprise and jobs.

Infrastructure:
The Kwame Nkrumah Circle/Interchange Project has taken off.
More roads are being built and rehabilitated all over the country.
Jobs will be created through this as well.

The President would focus on the economy and how we can correct its fundamental structure. He believes we are doing the right but tough things now for a better tomorrow.  He is confident that with the commitment and dedication of every Ghanaian in a position of responsibility these challenges can and will be resolved soon. The President has decided not to play a popularity game with our economy but to pursue prosperity that lasts.

God bless Ghana!
I wish to express my deepest condolences to the family of our brother Komla Dumor in this first day of his funeral rites. May God rest his soul in peace.
Ghana is the most stable country in West Africa. This is our most valuable asset when talking to potential foreign investors. Watch and please share.

The African pharmaceutical companies need international assistance to build local capacities and to produce the much-needed drugs against AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. Instead of the costly importation, African nations must be supported to manufacture these drugs at home. In brief, this is what I spoke about on Thursday at a high-level meeting of UNAIDS in London.

Regarding the depreciation of the Ghana Cedi, I want you all to know two major things. First: this is not caused by our national decisions. We are part of the global financial system and so we share both its ups and downs.

Since the beginning of this year, several countries, with stronger economies than ours, have seen their currencies depreciating due to the moves of international players on the stock market. In January, for instance, Argentina's peso fell more than 20%, Turkish lira lost 6%, the South African rand fell 7% and so did the Russian ruble.

The second thing I want you to be sure of is that the government is aware of the effect this depreciation has on your lives. We take all the proper measures to enable the Cedi to regain its strength against the US dollar and other major currencies. This is a short term challenge and we will fix it. Panic only worsens things in the financial market, so bear with the government, confident and fearless, because we will chart the path for recovery.
Don't let our personal energy be exhausted by those who can't see the forest for the trees.

I thank and salute the wise Ghanaian politicians who understand that the right attitude in such times is to assist the government and stop predicting disasters. Because, in a democratic country such as ours, the government is the people's government. It is your government. And it does everything necessary to lead our country and to attain the development goals it has announced. A nation has to be united when facing any kind of political or economic challenges.
Financial discipline will be our guiding principle.
We can and must do better.
Thank you for your comments and support.
2014 will be a year of actions. Your support is important to us.
Steps to making things happen for Ghana. Tell your friends about this.

I have tasked an advisory committee to work out the modalities for the establishment of the Ghana Infrastructure Fund. The six members of the committee have to prepare a business plan for this Fund, which I initiated to reduce our infrastructure deficit and to create more stable jobs for our people.
Please watch this video to see my commitment to Ghana's economic development.

We continue to improve Ghana's economy for the future of our families.

I know you had a difficult year. I know that financial problems may seem a neverending story and I can feel your uncertainty. I know very well the money worries that burden your minds and I understand the doubts regarding the future. That is why I want to tell you: Ghana is on the right path.

At Davos Economic Forum, I told the Japanese Prime Minister, Shinzo Abe, that Africa is now a better place to do business, so we encourage them to come and invest in our country.

Foreign investment is important, but growing the domestic private sector is also important. In the past, we were used to give incentives to foreign investors in order to come to invest, but not extending those incentives to our domestic private sector. I think that is changing now. With the new regulations that are coming out and the new laws that are coming out, we're extending incentives to both foreign investors and also to domestic investors. And so we're levelling the playground for everyone.

This is an important week for us. The political and business leaders I've met consider our country an example for Africa, so I use every opportunity to set new partnerships in the benefit of Ghana. Please share this.

Here is a fragment from what I said at the World Economic Forum, in the session "Africa's Next Billion", where I took part together with Nigeria's president, H.E. Goodluck Jonathan.
"A new class of poor people was generated in Africa in the 70's and 80's, when we all went through structural adjustment programs. We were asked to withdraw all subsidies, especially to the poorest of the poor, who were in agriculture. We were not allowed to subsidize agriculture. And, yet, in the West agriculture was heavily subsidized. And so it made our economies heavily import dependent, for even food!, chicken and things that we have a comparative advantage to produce, to feed ourselves... Rice! If you look at the huge amount of money that was spent in my country, 500 million dollars every year, to import rice, while we have the capacity to grow enough rice to feed ourselves...
So I think that structural adjustment created some problems. Now, the international financial institutions agree with us. They say - oh, yes, you can subsidize your farmers. And so we're making a change, we're seeing agricultural production grow up, we're seeing farmers rising to the occasion, we're changing the orientation of our farmers from being just peasant producers into seeing agriculture as a business. So a lot of things are changing and we're doing social protection programs to make people feel inclusive..."
Talking to Mrs. Hilde Schwab, wife of the founder of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland

I am more determined in my desire and ambition to build a prosperous, more stable, and more united nation with great opportunities for all.
Every Ghanaian deserves the best and I am constantly concerned about the plight and living conditions of every one of us.
I am confident about 2014 opening new doors for all Ghanaians.
We emerged winners out of the stormy clouds of uncertainty generated by the election petition that held back the vital flow of funds.
Together with the prayers, support and hard work of all Ghanaians we stayed strong as we tackled the devastating impact of fire outbreaks.
I have been working hard to move our prospects onto a strong and steady path that should truly make our nation great and strong.

"It is no coincidence that in the years since Mandela’s release so much of Africa has turned toward democracy and the rule of law. His utilization of peace as a vehicle of liberation showed Africa that if we were to move beyond the divisiveness caused by colonization, and the pain of our self-inflicted wounds, compassion and forgiveness must play a role in governance. Countries, like people, must acknowledge the trauma they have experienced, and they must find a way to reconcile, to make what was broken whole again."- President Mahama in a tribute to Nelson Mandela to be published by the New York Times shortly.

I remind you some words Professor Awoonor wrote while serving time in Ussher Fort prison: "At times the vision of victory comes so blurred and dim. So much is a haze, uncertainty. But somehow in this frame flickers a little light which keeps on the search, a veritable instrument around which hope settles, quietly, stirring now, slumbering now, but hanging on, just hanging on."

May God rest his soul in peace.

Message:
President John Mahama will on Monday inspect ongoing works on a new three-tier Kwame Nkrumah Interchange and cut the sod to officially commence construction. 

The project involves detailed engineering and construction of the old Circle into a three-tier interchange and other ancillary works including drainage, terminals, pedestrian walkways and landscaping.

The Kwame Nkrumah Circle has reached the limit of its capacity to contain the traffic passing through it daily. Over 84,000 vehicles approach the Circle from the arterial roads and other intersections feeding into the Circle daily. 

The project, when completed in two years, will effectively and efficiently tackle the traffic congestion challenges currently being experienced, ensure improved drainage and pedestrian safety among others. 

Please visit the YouTube channel below for an educational documentary on the project.

Happy Republic Day.

Dear friend, I guess you are back from church and taking care of other activities. Since I got back from church at around 10am, I have been holding various meetings and discussions all aimed at one goal, creating equal opportunities for all of us, in our quest towards building the Better Ghana we promised. And our country, I will repeat again, is blessed and making progress. 

Before the Republic Day weekend, I had a rare visit from selected pupils of the Flagstaff House Basic School, accompanied by their headmistress and some teachers to welcome me into their community. The pupils were all made up of prefects of the school. Taking them round my office, I enjoyed the experience and look forward to such opportunities in future to interact with our young ones. 

There should be some photos of this interaction on the flickr page. 
--- JM

Message:
Some lovely photos from this morning's walk have been posted to the flickr page of the Communications Bureau. Click to view. 
Thanks.
---JM

I joined the Elwak Keepfit Club, as I have done over the last four years, on a 15km Republic Day Walk. Always a refreshing thing to do, but as I advised the participants this morning, it should not be an occasional activity. You need to take good care of yourself. There are too many lifestyle diseases which we can avoid by exercising daily and eating the right choice of foods. 

Happy Republic Day in advance and on Monday I will on your behalf host a luncheon for our senior citizens, and there is also the finals of the 2013 Presidents Cup in the afternoon of the same day. 

Enjoy the weekend and the holiday.  
--- JM

President John Mahama today joined the generality of South Africans and the family of former South African President Nelson Mandela in praying for the Madiba "in this critical stage of his life", Information Minister Mahama Ayariga has disclosed. 

Speaking at the Daily Press Briefing at the Flagstaff House, Kanda, on Thursday, Mr. Ayariga said the President like others across the world is monitoring very closely the health situation of the former South African leader. 

Mr. Mandela has been in hospital for a recurring lung infection, and is said to be in critical condition. President Jacob Zuma has in his latest update on the former leader's condition assured South Africans that doctors were doing their best to ensure the wellbeing and comfort of the apartheid freedom fighter.

Ghana has yet again been recognised for working hard to reduce hunger and undernourishment, from a prevalence of 40.5% in 1990-92 to less than 5% in 2010-2012. Ghana has therefore achieved the Millennium Development Goal One. 

The number of undernourished people in the country has also been reduced from 6.16 million people in 1990-92 to less than 2 million in 2010-12, achieving the rather ambitious World Food Summit target.  

At a special event held at the FAO headquarters in Rome, Italy, Ghana's progress was celebrated with an award for notable and outstanding progress in flighting hunger. 

Ghana was one of only eighteen countries in the world, and one out of only two that came from Africa to win the prestigious award. The reduction in the prevalence of hunger and undernourishment is based on the Food & Agriculture Organisation's (FAO) most recent estimates. 

Minister for Food & Agriculture Clement Kofi Humado received the award on behalf of President John Mahama at the Rome event. He was accompanied by three Best Farmers. 

Mr. Humado in his acknowledgement, attributed the progress made to the country's hardworking farmers and fishers. He also pledged the country's continued effort to eradicate hunger and undernourishment from the remaining pockets mainly in Northern and the Southern Savannah areas of the country.
